title: Kanye West and Kim Kardashian took church service to Howard University
text:
’13th Amendment, Gotta end it, that’s on me,’ he sang (Picture: Howard University)

Kanye West and Kim Kardashian took their church service to Howard University this weekend, performing to students and members of faculty.

But the rapper left some fans shocked as he sang ’13th Amendment, Gotta end it, that’s on me’.

Grammy-award winning R&B singer Tony Williams led the service which included a brass band and a choir.

But not everyone at the DC-based HBCU was impressed.

Greg Carr, the chairman of Howard’s Department of Afro-American Studies, taking to Twitter to share: ‘If @kanyewest is indeed at #HowardU this morning, send him to the third floor of the Founder’s Library after he’s done.

‘I have some books for him.’

Keneshia Grant, another professor at the University, added: ‘This Kayne [sic] church thing makes me uncomfortable. There, I said it.’

His lyrics come a year after he faced backlash for a similar sentiment, tweeting that the 13th amendment should be abolished; the amendments abolished slavery and involuntary servitude, except as punishment for a crime.

Kanye later clarified that he meant to say it should be amended but his lyrics on Saturday revealed he felt it needed to be ‘ended’.

Kanye West is a fan of Donald Trump (Picture: Getty)

In the past two years, he has been highly criticised for his support of President Donald Trump.

Following a controversial appearance on Saturday Night Live in 2018, he told audiences he was bullied backstage into not wearing the MAGA hat and suggested that President Trump was not the bad guy.

‘You see they laughing at me. You heard ’em, they scream at me, they bully me.

‘They bullied me backstage they said, “Don’t go out there with that hat on.”

‘They bullied me backstage. They bullied me,’ he said.

Removing his MAGA hat, he continued: ‘And then they say I’m in a sunken place. You want to see the sunken place? Okay, I’ma listen to y’all now.’

He then put the hat back on and said: ‘Or I’ma put my Superman cape on, which means you can’t tell me what to do.’
